author: oaklandmatt
content:
Oliver power tools and kshmr are the most useful and most modern packs. Not sure what kind of music you're making but for my workflow I like doing whatever I feel on a production and then having quick "modern" drum sounds I can reach for that immediately can put things into the present.

I'm doing a production right now for a UK artist where they gave me a throwback sounding demo, but I know the artist is a young 2023 female pop star. So I did a bunch of organic shit (acoustic through my 67, some live claps, shit like that), then I threw some kshmr and oliver loops in to just see what the hybrid of classic and modern sounds like. Production is basically done now

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
@BatMeckley is the resident Grammy Loser on this topic, but I’ve made a decent living doing some indie and major label stuff as a vocal producer. 

Deliverables really depend on the producer you’re working with. In my experience it’s 50/50 whether they want tuned or raw, comped or all the takes- etc. 

The key things that keep me getting called are, in no particular order:

Communication. Everybody knows what to expect and what is to be expected. 

Professionalism. The room is clean, mics are up, lighting is right, session is loaded. 

Intuition. All the artistic/personal things. Making the artist feel safe enough to be dangerous, knowing how hard you can push them to get a take, knowing where the line is between their vision and yours, etc…

Sonics. I want my artists to feel expensive when they’re recording, so getting the mic and cue mix right is everything. 

Speed. A comp up by the time they’re done tracking, a quick shine to make it feel special, and a bounce for them to take with them.

Everything else is on a per session basis. I can deliver a fully mixed/tuned vocal and everything in between, so it all depends on communication ahead of time.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I had a similar moment when I moved to Los Angeles. I wrote Michael Beinhorn a really nice letter after I was inspired by his book, with the offer to be his assistant. The timing didn't work out because he had a newborn and was leaving LA, but I *did* get to sit down with him for drinks a few times. 

The big moment for me in those discussions was realizing that I was never going to be a great pop music producer *in addition* to everything else that I wanted to do. There are people out there who are 100% bought-in to that idiom and are going to absolutely smoke me because they *love* it. My takeaway was that in order to excel you have to lean into the things only you can do because no one else cares about them as much as you do and no one else is prepared to put in the same effort to see it realized.

author: Slow Hand
content:
So obviously starting with the right bass is going to get you 70% of the way there, but you know what *really* surprised the hell out of me? The *strings*. 

If you're not getting anywhere close to the tone that you want, start exploring the wide world of bass strings. I had overlooked this simple thing for ages. I took my choice of strings for granted because I never had to change them. And when I did it made all of the difference in my tone.

I've always been a Fender guy: P-basses and J-Basses, and the DI signal was always voiced way too dark to pop out of a mix without some heavy lifting. Granted I also use flatwounds (which aren't as zippy as roundwounds). 

After some research on the TalkBass forum, I ordered a few different sets of flats to experiment. One such set were the *Thomastik-Infeld Jazz Flats*, and ho-lee *shit*. There it was. There was the sound I was looking for.

They were voiced way lighter in the bass, which gave me a far more articulate midrange. Like the sound of an upright bass which (trust me) is a very good quality to have unless you're going for a grindy metal tone. As it turns out, the midrange is where *all* of the action is in the bass. It's okay if your bass DI is voiced with no low-end, because you can always add that weight back in, but if the midrange is not present to begin with it is an uphill battle to make it articulate in a mix.

author: BatMeckley
content:
It’s neat that there’s so many different approaches to producing a record, some people like Albini are almost strictly engineers capturing the artist warts and all, other people like mutt and fields are replaying everything and singing 90% of the BVs. (Once you hear Max Martin sing you can’t unhear him on all those boy band (and even Brittney) tracks. 

It’s such a weird balance of the ego, because as a producer you have to be arrogant enough to go “your art should sound like THIS” but you have to be humble enough to know when your idea isnt the best one. An up and coming pop band im far more likely to hard tune and really lock in their performances, where as if im cutting a Nels Cline or a Mimi Parker im more apt to go “well shit, that’s not what I would do, but who am I to try and dictate to you how to sound… here’s my gentle suggestion and if you say no, cool”

My general rule is put in the work, then take a step back, take a deep breathe, and try to accurately assess which is better… that decision you make is REALLY what defines you as a producer. So so so much of what I do ends up on the cutting room floor, but I wouldn’t have gotten to the end result without it.

author: BatMeckley
content:
<deep breath>
So, grasshopper, everything matters, and nothing matters. It depends on where you are and where you’re going, and most importantly actually knowing where you’re going.

I view the difference in shitty gear vs good gear as compound interest. A vintech one on one might sound basically like a vintage neve. ALMOST indistinguishable. But if you’re using it on all 149 of the tracks you’re compiling into a pop song, the end result is going to be 149 times more noticeable. The second floor of the leaning tower of Pisa looks pretty spot on but the people on the 15th floor are freaking out. 

That said, I could record a garbage singer through my 251 and my chain, and if I didn’t know what to do with it, it would still be garbage. The flip side is we actually demoed different mics and different chains on Paris Hilton. There was a right answer. And she’s not gonna win any singing contests, but at the end of the day the cumulative effect of all the decisions we made led to tracks that are still being played in clubs to make people dance over a decade later.

Details matter in not just what the audience hears eventually, but what the artist hears initially, giving them the confidence and headspace to sprinkle in their extra few (sometime more than a few) percentage points of vibe that the audience attaches too later. Fix it in the mix is an abused concept because it doesn’t take in to account the affect of shitty sound or feel on the performance. You think 1 mic doesn’t matter? I’ve heard people sing noticeably more in tune and in time when switching from DAW monitoring to direct monitoring. It ALL matters.

But if you don’t understand songs, melody, rhythm, and how these things interact to move people? None of it matters.

author: ALXCPH
content:
I've been a "musician" since way before i started recording and producing stuff. (Since i was 4 i think). It's such an integral part of how music can feel and make you move. Think about how someone like Anderson paak. can make you dance by just playing 8th notes on a highhat and nothing else(see tinydesk for ref.) or Pino Paladino, will make you break your neck with his bass, playing simple Quater notes. (anything D'angelo).  Even in a genre that is as quantized and on the grid as it gets like a lot of hiphop/trap is, notice how the artist(rappers) that really stand out, are the ones that make those beats really groove/hit because of how they themselves "groove" or flow on those beats. They might be slightly behind or in front of the beat, or they might even swing a little. 

You can really get into the micro and macro dynamics of groove. Listen to guys like Led zeppelin, how they might start out a song a few BPM slower than they finish, because of the build up of energy through out the song, and it doesn't sound wrong or unnatural. 

A fun thing to do, when looking for inspiration for grooves, is record some foley, and look for naturally occurring rhythms in the sample. Try and build a grove around that probably a bit wonky rhythm. It can really be an eye opening experience once you realise how much fun rhythm and groove is, when you don't have to obey the grid in a daw like a machine. 

But like anything music, it's really about listening and feeling. Really internalising what a forward or laid back snare feels like or a bass thats almost a 16th behind the beat.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Granted, her examples are *very* specific to orchestra and not directly applicable to pop records, but the underlying principles here include:

**1) **Think of instrument combinations as a single composite voice.

One instrument can function as the "sustain" portion of the sound and a second instrument gives the "attack". Together they create a single melodic voice.

**2) **How do the instruments stack on each other? Do they clash? Cellos doubling a bass an octave up extend it's timbre into a higher register to make it read better. It's not so different from adding fuzz to an 808 so that it has more presence.

**3) **Which instrument will cut through the music?

---

A few concepts that I'll add:

**4) **Instruments in the foreground vs. the background. Know which part is the lead (focal point) at any given point in the record and then pare down the presence of the rest and push it into the back of the sound stage.

**5)** (Piggybacking off of Felix's excellent post) What is the simplest way to achieve the desired effect? Reduce. Reduce. Reduce.

Cut instruments and parts ruthlessly and approach it with a minimalist's eye. Like writing a haiku: How few elements can you use to create an impression? Maybe a guitar part is carrying 90% of the groove and the drums only need to be a kick and a snare. Or maybe the guitar is covering the backbeat too, and you don't even need a snare!

Constantly ask yourself "What is the most important sensation in the record?" and then focus it by cutting out everything that gets in the way.

**6)** Hocketing. Pass the melody off between different instruments at different points in the song. Play it in different registers. Combine voices occasionally for special effect.

**7)** Tonal contrast. Dark instruments plus bright instruments. Distorted and clean together. Near vs. distant.

Elements that sound same-y will gel together and elements that contrast tonally will pop.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Has anyone checked out the massive update that Ableton just released for their *Learning Synths* website? 

I wish I didn't know a thing about synths so that I could experience it fresh. It's a brilliant site and a great resource for learning the fundamentals of synthesizers. *Strong* recommend, even if you already know that domain.

They've done something really cool, in that you can play a patch in the browser as they're teaching you, pop the hood and tweak it if you want to go deeper *and then* you can download the patch you've been playing with as a Live session that you can then open in Live and continue creating with it.

That might sound pretty simple, but the execution is brilliant. It's very fun.

https://learningsynths.ableton.com/en/get-started

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@Zack Hames yeahhhh. watch the questlove video on youtube where he talks about d'angelo asking him to play crazy laid back and flammy too.

my general thought on timing is: behind the beat is more groovy and laid back (vocals, percussion, bass against the kick drum, etc) and ahead is intense and anxious (especially vocals).

there are many examples of groove being behind the beat as that's something people talk about a lot. definitely dive into that concept and play with laying different elements back off the grid.

but i LOVE talking about being ahead of the beat. purists complain that a lot of modern hip hop vocals are ahead of the beat and "off time." but when it's done well it makes the tracks SO exciting. lil durk, 21 savage, gucci, etc all have this excitement in some of the songs because the vocal are ahead. 

i've heard the argument that these guys are just amateurish in their skill. that might be true, but their natural groove and cadence works. also listen to kendrick on "Family Ties" where he goes in and out of being ahead of the beat and it sounds exciting as fuck when he does.

also "Icky Thump" by White Stripes is a song with vocals that are entirely ahead of the beat. clearly it's deliberate as jack white is a rhythmic genius (and the doubles are perfect). it adds this anxiety to the whole song that is SO dope.

author: LAPhill
content:
Okay @Nomograph Mastering , so I think the analogy is a little off. Music is a conversation, but it's a conversation between performers. At it's best, the performance is authentic, transcendent, and speaks to our souls in a way that real-world conversation with words can't do. But it's heightened, exaggerated, hyper-focused. If the song is written ahead of time, it's more akin to actors interpreting a script. The words are written, the notes are there. Unless we're talking about jazz improvisation, which is the closest we come to real world conversation, but even then, it's translated and performed. As much as Miles was saying what he wanted to say, he was saying it that way so that an audience would hear it, it wasn't a private conversation.

Now, if you get incredible actors on a stage or in front of a camera, you can let them do their thing with minimal trickery, minimal edits, and it will move you to tears. The respond to each other and elevate the piece beyond what feels possible. Watch that same play as a community theater-level performance and feel nothing. The reality is that a lot of the artists that are coming through aren't Sidney Poitier. They're just not that good at making their music feel effortless. Not every play works as a film, and vice versa. Not every track benefits from having a band in a room. 

Confusing the genesis of songwriting (one person crafting both sides of a conversation) with the act of expressing that work (one person performing every part, a la Tom Hanks' motion capture of every character in The Polar Express). I know that ultimately you and I agree on the benefits of humans recording together, but the analogy feels too blurry to me.

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
2 helpful things come to mind:

1) my go to technique for that sampled sound is too record the instrument an octave higher, and twice as fast. then based on your desired decade, put RC-20, sketch cassette, lossy, etc on that octave higher, twice as fast part. render this. Now stretch this rendered audio twice as long so its in the right octave and right speed. The key here is that your lofi plugin is on BEFORE you pitch around the audio.

2) as you already keyed in on, the more mono you go, the more lofi / grungey / busted, something will sound.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I’ve been thinking about @Joel "Roomie" Berghult‘s question re: mixing as you since he asked it. I think what Rauirí says about not knowing what we’re doing while we’re doing it is really true, so I’ve just been trying to dissect my process in my brain, away from the computer.  I think it comes down to 2 things for me. 

Here are my thoughts:


1) Choosing Sounds. 

In addition to vibe & genre & emotional intent, each instrument or sample that you pick covers a certain area of the overall picture. Knowing where that part is going to go in the overall arrangement changes how much hi end or low end or wetness (etc.) you want. It also steers performances. 

2) Actually Mixing As You Go 

Once a part is recorded, do a quick adjustment so that you hear closer to a finished product. This helps you make better choices about what else needs to be added, (or not added,) and will likely inspire the next step.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Three things come to mind: 

1) **Note length and envelope**. That's going to have a large influence on the feel. Electronic producers will spend a *lot* of time sculpting the volume envelope relative to the tempo. Trance producers have entire plugins that give them microscopic control over the pitch and volume envelopes of kick drums.

2) **Presentation and proportion**. Is it up-front or does it sink into the back? It's easy for a 4x4 to feel hackneyed or overbearing. Sometimes all you need is a gentle *pat pat pat pat* to tie things together.

A fresh or unconventional texture will open up drastically different feels. People can dance to anything if it's got a 4x4 click, so it doesn't necessarily *need* to be a kick. You can go far using samples and percussion that sit in different registers, but play the same role.

3) **Complimentary instruments**. If the kick is the "rock" then the groove is going to come from how everything else swings over that. What's the friction like between the kick and the other elements? If the kick is a "straight man", then the other elements pushing off of it are where the magic comes from.

author: Slow Hand
content:
There's no right way to go about sound selection, but ultimately you have to use your intuition and taste to judge if they're right for the record you're making. If the sounds don't seem to fit, then perhaps you need to ask yourself what effect it is that you're going for in the first place. Why are you trying to put *those* two sounds together? Decide if they get you close to that goal. If not, then simply find another sound. Not everything needs to work.

A lot of it comes down to intention and conviction. "Wrong" notes or sounds that are dramatically different can still be pulled off if you play them with confidence and panache. Records are full of sonic choices that stick out like a sore thumb, and we can make them sound coherent with conviction. What might sound abrasive and weird at first can easily become habituated and familiar with enough exposure.

I think almost any combination is valid. There are sound choices that are conventional and there are choices that go against the grain. Every unconventional choice is an opportunity to create a new genre or to create a new mood. It can be a matter of mindset. If you can free yourself from the need to do the "right" thing then the creativity to play with unusual combinations will come a lot easier.

Of course, this is all hard to discuss without hearing examples. If you can give us more examples of what you're dealing with perhaps we can be more specific.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah, this is a really cool approach to metronome. I once worked with an engineer who had a drum machine/sequence set up where he could fade in and blend different rhythmic subdivisions. (1/4, 1/4t, 1/8, 1/8t, 16, etc...) The samples were all shakers and pleasant sounding percussion. It was way more musical than getting pummeled by the worlds crispest woodblock on the quarter-note pulse.

He said he'd developed it after doing a lot of slow doom-y metal records that grind along at ultra-slow tempos and where the players are playing very spacious but angular rhythmic parts that needed to come in on the "+ e" of beat 3 after a 4 bar rest. Stuff like that. Having 1/16t subdivisions alongside the 1/4 pulse was really helpful for the players to come in strong when they needed to catch a really tough entrance.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Another example:

On Brett’s last record, he did a demo with a co-writer of a song I loved. he tracked vocals with me, and I suggested the track needed a Mayer style guitar solo, so I played it. When Dann Huff heard it he told Brett “we’ll just upgrade Noah’s track to Master Scale. It’s not gonna get any better than that.”

When they went into the studio, they ended up taking the Mayer idea all the way, and the whole thing kinda went Country “Don’t Trust Myself.” They couldn’t do a Mayer solo on top of a Mayer vibe cause it would go from inspired by to straight derivative. 

My solo didn’t make the record, and I didn’t get any production credit. But the guy who did the demo did. I did get some BGVs on it and paid accordingly. All that felt right to me.

author: Zach Hughes

I was focused heavily on production work over the summer and then when my schedule loosened up in the Fall I started writing for my next album. I had done a little brainstorm session with chatGPT actually to help me create a daily schedule oriented solely around writing which was pretty helpful. But even when still in the production grind I like having guitars laying around so I can grab one when I take a break or bring on in the house with me. If you have the flexibility, w/o compromising deadlines, I've found it helpful to leave room to indulge the moments when songs / melodies / lyrics pop into my head even when my expectation that day was to work on a mix or other production. Be interrupted by the song and push everything else back an hour and see what happens.

author: spectrummasters
content:
It’s giving steel banglez and the Afro swing sound he made popular about 6 or 7 years ago in London ? Then we got the trap wave . Interesting one imho because there’s an unsettled debate as to whether the dembow , soca and other clave and tresillo derived pulses gave rise to the Afro beats wave that popped off in london years back (and steel banglez finessed so successfully into his (great ) productions) or if those Afro Cuban / carribean forms that have existed for hundreds of years are fundamentally derivative of the west african forms (eg nyabinghi and early New Orleans drum lines being deliberately so ) and so even if Afro beat reappropriated some carribean forms for its own modern genesis , it was only using what it gave birth to in the first place . 

Imho these beats today sit as a uk post modern take on the product of all of these wonderful rhythms from the diaspora, and like the people the rhythms themselves are all kin . I’m sure Interested also if that particular beat can be pinned down to an early african or Afro carribean form

My Mrs dad is sierra leonian creole . Which is to say his heritage is to have been the people that returned back to Sierra Leone from Jamaica . Much of the sierra leionian creole culture is a blend of carribean and west african and The music and culture tends to be somewhere along this journey most times . It travels with the people and their story is the story of the music

author: cy (sigh)
content:
@Ross Fortune  @spectrummasters 

pretty much hit the nail on the head on a lot of it. it does have a basic name and was originally mostly popular in West and Central Africa, where msot of the slaves that went to the Caribbean were from.  I'm just blanking out on the name rn. 

that rhythm, or a form of it present in almost all popular Caribbean styles of music. 

reggae, reggeaton, dancehall, zouk, konpa, salsa, soca etc all have their versions of it w some of them essentially not having any difs. 

i think things kind of went full circle for various cultures. rose of reggeaton in the 90s in the Caribbean (2000s in the US) which became the first Caribbean genre after reggae/dancehall  to really hit the international stage hard brought a lot of those back to the forefront.  

around the same time a boom in zouk / konpa music started happening in African countries (a lot of acts started touring there). 


afro house then afro pop and all subcategories started making rounds in Europe (at least the French speaking countries)  and the Caribbean in 2010s and hitting  us soil full strength a couple years after that (w some exceptions)

all this culminating in the now where you'd be hard pressed to not here a handful of these rhythms on the radio in most countries. even I was surprised that one of the biggest intl hits was a haitian song and they ended up having a remix w burna boy. 

but yeah I find it super interesting how the same core  rhythms is delivered under so many names.

author: Slow Hand
content:
If you know your way around a synthesizer, Massive X and Serum 2 are both heavy hitters that cover all of my bases. 

Sonically, Massive X has a "warmer" voicing and has all of NI's amazing effect algorithms built into it. Everything sounds incredible and is dripping with character. It's absurdly capable, but the interface may be overwhelming at first. It can be a lot to get oriented on. It's impossible for this thing to sound "cold". The preset library is less bass music/EDM and more balanced. NI offers a lot of genre-themed expansions. If you like programming sequenced/heavily automated one-button patches Massive X is king.

Serum is on the "cold" side, but just as capable of "warmer" sounds. The sonics and DSP are clear as a bell. Stellar. It's more intuitive to program and the feature set is an embarrassment of riches. It's absurd how much functionality Steve and team crammed into it. Absolutely absurd. If you want to do EDM and bass music, it's the king and it's preset library leans towards that. I still cannot believe that they *gave* it away to Serum 1 users.

Both excel at cinematic and over the top. If you're looking for the "classic" sound, I'd lean Massive X.

author: popaganda.
content: There are some traps with Lego music that can be overcome with a little intention. For instance, we all kinda know the standard contours of a pop song….in Lego music you pretty much accomplish this by addition and subtraction of arrangement elements, but in the live days musicians would contour a song with the energy/intensity of their playing, and when a rhythm section is tracking together someone is usually leading that charge and everyone’s riding that energy wave together into the last chorus or whatever

author: popaganda.
content: Well yeah, doing anything won’t make you great unless you do it greatly. But my point is that if you feel you’ve been making boxy music a way out of that trap is to conceive parts more linearly and play down a whole take with an energy contour rather than add and subtract elements for the energy shifts

yes agreed, production wise you can follow those roland drum kits pretty much through every decade to this day. its amazing to me that a number of todays budding producers can name these things partially, for example referring to the Roland 808 Kick Long and not know anything about the Roland 808, let alone the other modules. ......and parrallel to the "808 ", the 909 is still to this day, going strong in house with the likes of MK . author: Will Trotman
content:
In addition to the diamonds like Noah said, just root notes chugging away or playing 8th notes can be helpful and non invasive if chords or power chords feel too informative. Octaves can be a cool halfway point. A lot of songs seem to have room for the clean “dinky” sort of electric parts (sometimes slightly melodic or sometimes just hanging out on a single note).

If it’s a matter of filling space, something that helped me on a pop track the other day was making a second track for echoes of the lead vocal where you can low pass it pretty hard and delay / verb it out.

I often find myself introducing subtle sub basses later in the song, potentially doubling electric bass with synth bass, maybe layering snares to be fatter in later choruses. Then playing with some subtle percussion elements like triangle, clave, wood blocks, to differentiate later choruses.

author: Slow Hand
content:
*Keyscape* has some fantastic sounding (and unorthodox) sampled keyboard instruments. That said I'm not particularly fond of the sound of it's LA Custom C7 grand piano. Which is a little too hi-fi for my taste.

Lately I've been very impressed by NI's/Kontakt's *The Maverick* grand piano. I believe it's a vintage Bechstein grand. The sound is robust and rich without all of the "zing" that I see in a lot of full-scale sampled grand pianos. It sounds "woody" to me. I think it would make for a very nice jazz piano.

They did a really good job of sampling every facet it and it has enough flexibility that you can dial in the really intimate Nils Frahm-style damper/pedal/mechanical noises, which I like.

author: peterlabberton
content: I’ve done this a few different ways as well—once, both songs were mixed in the same session, and then bounced separately for mastering. (FWIW, that Pro Tools session became an absolute nightmare—wouldn’t necessarily recommend this method unless there is some reason to do so. In this case we had effects/elements from the first song pop up later on in the second song.) I left blank space in the second song’s bounce so they could be lined up perfectly. Other times I’ve taken a stereo bounce of one song and dropped it into the mix session for the other just to mock things up as we go. What happens on the mastering side I am less familiar with… but if it’s something specific we’re after I’ll usually send along a reference of the exact timing/fade/etc. for them to match.

author: KushKadett
content: Dub and raggae from that era was made on old BBC consoles (very hifi and not lofi gritty in my book) There's an engineer giving a masterclass on dub mixing on youtube (great video, highly recommend it!)  and he explains how it's kind of a misconception that their equipment was all ghetto when in actuality they had incredible world class stuff left over from the brits after they left, which rivals what the best studios use even today. Analog gear hasn't really progressed much and a pultec/Neve EQ is still one of the best EQs ever for instance. Those records still sound great for that reason. As for punk and hardcore it's interesting: do people genuinely still listen to those records? I've revisited a few old punk records which I used to think were amazing. The songs are great but the listening experience just isn't enjoyable for me anymore, in part due to messy playing  and bad recording/mixing. With bad I mean the playing distracts from the groove of the band and the mixing distracts from the song, where it does not support the dynamic shifts

author: peterlabberton
content:
I think the example of great punk/post punk/early indie records is perfect: great music but poor sonic quality and sloppy playing—at least by many peoples’ standards. The Replacements Let It Be is fucking rad, but would I use that as a mix reference for how I want something to *sound*? No!

On the other side of the coin, I feel like a *ton* of current/recent music can sound really good from a technical production/sonic perspective, but be totally void of any emotion that I connect to. So would I ever put it on to listen to for pleasure? No!

author: Slow Hand
content:
Bowie being perceptive as always. 

The question that comes up in my mind is "Where are the new innovations happening today?" The incubation period for new musical styles is much smaller than it used to be, pre-internet. 

Musical innovations don't live in obscurity for very long these days. They get widely disseminated and integrated into existing styles far more quickly. If a group of teens in Mumbai create something fresh it may be days or weeks before it gets shared with the rest of the world and before other creators start integrating it. Whereas early hip hop had years - nearly a decade, by some counts - to gestate and find itself before it spread outside of New York and was co-opted by the greater world.

I wonder if we've lost something in that tradeoff. We gain quicker access to art and ideas around the world, but we pre-emptively bring these musical mutations out into the daylight before they have time to grow into something unique. Something that is fully formed by it's local environment.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I've always loved Vulfpeck's approach. For the first few albums every single tracking take was filmed on an iPhone while they recorded in their living room/bedroom/etc, which allowed Jack Stratton to turn around and release low budget music videos for every single song on the album using the take that made the album.

Their setup was always lo-fi and charmingly janky in the edit. They just leaned into the artifice of a low-grade camera and built their whole visual style around these simple phone captures of the session.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I asked a similar question a while ago, and @oaklandmatt had a great answer basically to the effect of: 
Something rushing ahead adds energy or anxiousness (a punk bass line or fast trap hihats, maybe a rock guitar solo)
Something late adds groove/swagger (Lofi hip hop snare, a lazy vocal, a funky bass line)
I think that’s a really cut and dry way to view it; but what you said obviously applies, every context is different.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
yeah its very case by case. as far as groove in relation to other elements. I've had guitars recorded loosely toa click and worked the groove around that - lining up the downbeats of the drums/bass  with the guitars even if it's a bit early or late. that was for a more indie type of joint. and for something more trap /modern hip hop, I've nudged bass notes or samples to get them to either sync w drums up for impact  or nudge slightly off to hype of of pull back the energy in the groove. 

as far as programming. I'll play with forward swing and dragging notes a lot if I'm going for a more real/dynamic feel when programming. keeping in mind that if the goal is trying to stay "on time" any fwd swing that might happen at the start of a phrase will be compensated with some drag  after or vice versa.  keeping velocities in mind w drum hits + linking it to a filter env so that harder hits have more high end and softer hits end up a bit rounder.

adding subtle layers that are similar   to the main drums but occupy a different texture or tone  in dif  sections to thicken up the groove or automate the attack /sustain of certain elements thru diff sections to help shift the listener  focus throughout

author: Slow Hand
content:
(Ok. Now I'm starting to run with this train of thought. Now would be a good time to step off if you've gotten what you need.)

I don't want this to sound like the end-all be-all. One of my absolute favorites is James Brown, and there is no way that some of his songs would hold up to the level of scrutiny I'm describing. And those records *kill*. It's all vibe. It's vibe all the way down, bebe. Not a chord change in sight. Barely a melody in some cases. And that's alright.

So what did James do? More often than not James would get all of his band (real jazz killers) in the studio and he would sing the parts to them one by one and allow them to input their own feel.

He'd start with the drummer and have them play a pattern that James was feeling. Once the drummer was jamming on that he would move on to the bass player and sing them an idea. Once the bass player had that germ of an idea they would continue to jam on it with the drummer, refining and adding their own thing. Then James would move on to the horns, and so on, and so on.

While James could be dictatorial and (from the perspective of music education) the least technically qualified person in the room he had *vision*. 

If the song has a strong identity you can give your players a good (non-technical) prompt and they can interpret that through their own sensibilities. You can describe a mood, or a scene, or an abstract sensation.

R. Kelly once said (I'm paraphrasing): "RnB is supposed to feel like the best moment of your *life*." That simple description conveys so much about the feel, the pleasure, and the joy that he is looking for in his music. It also excludes a lot of possibilities as well. If you can give your players a prompt like *that* then you can get everyone aligned on the same wavelength and it will carry you so much further without the need to dictate parts.

----

author: Slow Hand
content:
Ahhh gotcha. That's a cool goal.

So it sounds like part of what you're seeking are techniques to add pitched resonance to samples that may be atonal?

Well a resonator is a great start. If you're not already into it, I'd look into the karplus-strong theorem and physical modeling synthesis. That whole field has a lot of overlap with what you're describing. It's the kind of thing you'd hear Sophie or Jimmy Edgar do with their Elektron Monomachine.

*AAS* have a whole suite of physical modeling products that function similar to *resonator*, but are third-party plugins. Doing percussion synthesis with *Chromaphone* can do a pretty convincing recreation of certain percussion tones with the added bonus of being as flexible as a synthesizer, because it is a synthesizer!

You could tune a high-feedback delay unit until it rings at the pitch you're seeking. I can elaborate if you need more explanation. Funnily, that's the entire basis for physical modeling synthesizers.

Alternately, you could layer your samples with gently-blended sine tones. That's worth a try too. I know a lot of EDM producers are into this.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
1) what are the top 5 most important things for you in purchasing a drum sample pack ?


I never purchase drum sample packs - not since having Splice. I do like a clear identity in a pack though - for instance, The Kount's sample pack has all those lo-fi/saturated kicks and snares, wonky grooves and crusty hi hats etc that sit very much in his genre, so if I'm reaching for that sound, I know exactly where to go. 

I don't know your drummer or his band, but I'd wonder what distinctive character you could capture in your pack? So that I know exactly where to go when I want "that" sound in a writing session instant. 


2) I’m always annoyed that all samples are 0.0db normalized and I always have to turned them way down to keep my gain staging coherent, would I be crazy to have them peak at -8 ? Would people automatically hate it ? 

I produce largely in Ableton now, and when you drop a sample in the drum rack, the instance of Simpler it creates defaults to -12dB. With the velocity:volume dial at default (45%), this causes a 0dB sample to play back at -6dB when velocity=100 (the default). My template has all mixer faders (including a basic drum rack + instance of Drum Buss) trimmed to -9dB (similar to my mix gain staging strategy I detailed previously), allowing me to mash stuff up if needed, and still have headroom to not have to max out vocals when it comes to cutting them. What I'm saying in a roundabout way is... I've already made allowances for 0dB samples, so I don't care - but you probably should, because if you're selling on Splice, they could sound dwarfed against the next pack.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think the band Secret Chiefs 3 is a good glimpse at what a truly pan-musical approach could be like. Though they are far from pop music. 

They're drawing on a wide variety of musical systems: Western diatonicism, Messiaen-ic (lol) scales, Azerbaijani mugham, Afghani traditionals, Italian avant-garde film score, surf rock, and so on.

They integrate a lot of different tuning systems and rhythmic approaches into their compositions. Trey Spruance has said on a few occasions that their seemingly arabic-sounding music would sound just as foreign to an arab musician as it would to an American listener. They embody a real ethos to fuse as much of these musics together.

https://open.spotify.com/track/2qHkwrDOfg291jbrQbb91z?si=dd5397e501784b3a

author: Rob Domos
content: All postulating and math talk aside, for me it just comes down to the fact that I prefer the sound of not randomizing the bottom bit in a 24 bit file. At 16 bits that noise is preferable to the audible quantization error but at 24 it’s not for me. After 3 EDM dudes with solid careers (including luca pretolesi) said this exact same thing to me about dithering, I tried it and agreed

author: BatMeckley
content:
But you can’t control their behavior, just yours. I feel like we’re moving the goal posts here a bit… i know some pretty verifiably shitty human beings that are massively successful songwriters, and people look the other way because they consistently deliver. 

My Dad used to have this concept he called “would you throw your dog off a roof”… people would always ask him in the lean years “why do you play these shitty state fairs all the time” and he would respond with that analogy… “would I throw my dog off the roof for $100? NO. Not for anything. He’s family. I love him.” Would you throw your dog off the roof for $100 million dollars? “Well he pisses on the carpet and he’s always barking at the mailman and…”

That example of where Metallica doesn’t work with Bob Rock anymore neglects to take into account that they’re in the very rare air where it doesn’t really matter how well the records do anymore, and having said that the foundation that BR helped build ensured a fan base that will make sure any new record won’t totally tank regardless. So it doesn’t really apply to your situation.

author: Rob Domos
content: To be embarrassingly transparent, a lot of times I think a note is late by listening and then after looking find out it was early. Things just feel in time or out. Also, a lot of things that have loose rhythm in a way that people tend to love often bother me and sound out of time to me. Jay-Z is a perfect example of this. I spent years thinking his rhythm was terrible before I realized he was doing a shuffle time feel where the amount his vocal is off from the snare creates the shuffle. I just didn’t pick up on that for like… 15 years? And just wondered why nobody else was bothered him being “out of time”. Kind of like when people with an undeveloped sense of harmony think of jazz as simply being an excuse for allowing wrong notes. That’s how I hear people that are famous for stretching rhythm

author: Deleted User
content:
@RÜSSO Here a serum patch. It's close enough - but if you want it to be exactly the same then you'll likely have to find out what synth they used. You could try tweaking the waveform to a slightly different Saw wave, but this is probably as close you'll get with the Serum LPFs and enveloping. You'll need to mess around with pitch bend and attack time to get the performative aspect of this lead line, and especially when you do the pitch bend - you might need some help from the compressor to get the sustain out of that slow pitch bend,

Whenever you hear buzziness it's usually LFO on OSC level on a faster rate. This same lead sound is all over different styles of EDM so it's a good patch to know. Kaskade - Atmosphere has the same lead but in square wave with other layers as well.

author: Deleted User
content:
But I do want to clarify about my one take musician thing… 

I may have used the term too loosely. To me, most jazz musicians are one take players. They record everything together and calls it. (of course they do a few takes but I’m not trying to be a “first take and that’s it” player)

Being able to play through the whole song (unless arrangement calls for section by section) and just needing to punch in a few spots is what I want. I do not have any desires to go beyond that. 

BUT

I don’t ever want to edit my timing other than micro adjustments that can be done by moving small part of audio clip or hitting quantize. 

That + being more consistent with touch so I don’t have to punch in as much

author: rawssx
content: I was wrong about the tony berg thing, soo wrong. I dived into phoebe’s stuff just last week, funny that it took me 4 year to check out an Amazing album even thou i have been following her on instagram since 2020. What blew me up was, most of the modern productions in the pop side of industry, the sad songs, all of them are inspirationally ripping phoebe’s sound. I was mad at tony berg when i saw his interview where he gatekept a vst they used throughout the album to get that muffled texture. But in the past two days, i also realised he said “We are not going to tell you the vst just so you at home can not replicate the sound”. I thought that was asshollery until i realised that they are actually being ripped so hard in the industry and that they really gotta protect their sound. Tony, Phoebe, Ethan these guys are hidden unknown diamonds “i think (like me) a lot of people know phoebe as a celebrity than a music artist, or that was just me being lazy to check out her songs” but i feel like everyone needs to experience their music.

author: rawssx
content: Good for you, i am saying that as a listener, not as an analyst. And so does anyone who listens to sad pop music, the guy who found out about the vst on youtube he also mentioned “Everyone is trying to copy phoebe” that is true. Not only did they gatekeep the sauce lol, even the mic they recorded vocals on.

author: Juliette
content:
Something that I’m realizing that kind of screwed me a bit is that I grew up playing and recording a lot of heavy metal, and that turned into hours and hours of trying to perfect the method to get a huge, heavy song. I’ve watched quite a bit of Joey Sturgis, Fredrik Nordstrom, Zakk Cervini, Jordan Fish, Dan Weller, Will Putney— and the production/mix process became very technical at times, and that’s what I stuck with when it came to my projects as well. 

Delving into other genres has been extremely fun but my brain is still used to trying to be super technical rather than just enjoy the sound. :sigh:

author: Josh

author: Slow Hand
content: What do you mean it feels like hitting cardboard? Does the instrument have bad velocity mapping that feels unnatural? Or does it have poor response time when you use your electronic kit?

A pop track I'm producing on sounds great on the ears instrumentally and vocally, but I keep thinking it could have *more* going on to compliment it. Kind of like adding sprinkles onto a cake.
